title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SEATTLE (AP) — On a night where offensive struggles were the norm for everyone else, Gary Payton authored a masterpiece of pure, unadulterated will. The Seattle SuperSonics, powered by their point guard’s historic and relentless triple-double, grinded out a 93-79 victory over the Dallas Mavericks.

While the final score suggests a comfortable win, this was a defensive war of attrition, a game crying out for a hero. Payton answered that call with a performance for the ages, pouring in a game-high 42 points while hauling in 10 rebounds and dishing 11 assists. In a contest where his teammates combined for just 51 points, “The Glove” was not just the best player on the floor; he was the entire Sonics’ offensive system.

Dallas, led by a gritty 22 points from A.C. Green, simply had no answer. Payton’s scoring was a ruthless blend of mid-range jumpers and forceful drives into the teeth of the Mavericks’ defense. Every time Dallas threatened to close the gap, Payton had a response—a dagger three, a slick pass to a cutting teammate, or a tough offensive board to extend a possession.

His all-around dominance sucked the life out of the visitors, holding them to a mere 79 points on their home floor. This wasn't just a win; it was a statement carved from granite. In a low-scoring, physical battle, Gary Payton didn’t just beat the Mavericks. He conquered them, delivering a singular, iconic performance that will echo in the annals of Seattle basketball history.
